summary: This is an email chain from February 15, 2020, discussing logistical challenges in processing evidence from Epstein-related search warrants. An FBI contractor is communicating with an Assistant U.S. Attorney and others about a hard drive containing search warrant materials, expressing confusion over what data is new versus previously received and requesting a better tracking system.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The email is addressed to this person, who is the recipient of the hard drive containing Epstein search warrant materials and is being asked for guidance on data organization.

events.title: Modified date of initial load files
events.description: 38 folders labeled 'loadFiles' through '37loadFiles' on the hard drive have a modified date of November 14, 2019, which the sender believes may have been previously received.

events.title: Modified date of new evidence folder
events.description: A folder titled 'NYC024362' on the hard drive has a modified date of January 27, 2020, which the sender believes may contain new Epstein search warrant materials not previously received.

keyFacts: An FBI contractor is handling a hard drive containing Epstein search warrant materials and is confused about what data is new versus previously received.

The hard drive contains 38 folders labeled 'loadFiles' through '37loadFiles' with a modified date of November 14, 2019, potentially old data, and a folder 'NYC024362' with a modified date of January 27, 2020, potentially new data.
The folder 'NYC024362' alone contains more than 600,000 items, indicating a massive volume of evidence.
The sender emphasizes the need for a spreadsheet or tracking system to identify devices, extraction status, and materials transferred to avoid organizational disaster during review.
The communication highlights logistical challenges in evidence management within the Epstein investigation, involving coordination between an FBI contractor and the U.S. Attorney's Office.
